HERBERT GROSS: Hi, our lecture
today is about curve plotting.

And actually, I call it 'Curve
Plotting with and without Calculus' to emphasize the
fact that what we're

interested in is curve plotting
and that calculus, in particular, differentiation,
gives us a powerful tool that

is not available to us, at least
in an accessible form without the calculus.

Let's see what I mean by this
by going back to a typical high school type analytical
geometry problem.

For example, sketch the curve
'y' equals 'x squared'.

Now we all know that the graph
of 'y' equals 'x squared' is something like this.

And how'd we find that? You may recall that in the truer
sense of the word, the pre-calculus approach really is
curve plotting as opposed

to curve sketching. And I hope I make that
a little bit clearer as we go along. Namely, you look to see for
certain values of 'x' what

value of 'y' corresponds

corresponding point 'x' comma

'y' in the plane of
the blackboard. And what we then do is somehow
or other, take a French curve,

or whatever it happens to be,
and we sketch a smooth curve through the given points.

This is the usual technique. The question that comes up is,
that as long as there are spaces between the points that
you've sketched, how can you

be sure that the curve that
you've drawn isn't inaccurate? In other words, starting in
reverse here, let's suppose

that these are the points I've
happened to sketch for the curve 'y' equals 'x squared'. And by the way, as is often the

be misled that we pick something

with say, doing

something like this?  Why, for example, couldn't

Now again, notice that in
terms of mathematical

analysis, not necessarily
calculus but in terms of mathematical analysis, we could
immediately strike out

something like this. For example, notice in terms
of our input versus output,

this says that for any real
input since the square of a real number cannot be negative,

be negative. And pictorially, this means that

In other words, without

Well you see, armed with this

through something like this? That's what the question

not the graph of

'y' equals 'x squared'. But the question is, noticing

And again, we can get bailed
out by a pre-calculus knowledge of mathematics.

Among other things, notice the
rather interesting property that if we replace 'x' by 'minus
x' here, we get the

same curve as before. To generalize this result,
notice that in this particular

case, 'f of x' gives us
the same result as 'f of 'minus x''.

Now this will not happen
in general. What does that mean if we know
that 'f of x' equals 'f of

'minus x''? Well, look it. The relationship between 'x' and
'minus x' is clear, they

are located symmetrically with
respect to the y-axis.

In other words, if this is 'x1',
this will be 'minus x1'. Now, here's the point.

Let's suppose our curve
happens to be 'y' equals 'f of x'. When the input is 'x1', the
output will be 'f of x1'.

When the input is 'minus x1',
the output will be 'f of 'minus x1''.

To say that 'f of 'minus x1''
equals 'f of x1' is the same as saying that not only are
these two coordinates, 'x1'

and 'minus x1', symmetric with
respect to the y-axis, but the outputs also are.

In other words, to say that 'f
of x1' equals 'f of 'minus x1'', says that not only are
these two points the same left

and right displacement for the
y-axis, but they're also the same height above the x-axis.

In short, this point is the
mirror image of this point. In terms of a graph, if 'f of x'
equals 'f of 'minus x'' for

all 'x', the graph of 'y' equals
'f of x' is symmetric with respect to the y-axis.

By the way, that's why we could
rule out this type of possibility here.

For example, here's
'x1' over here. Here's 'minus x1'.

And notice that for this choice

of 'minus x'' tells us that

This leads us to a rather
interesting aside. It's something called 'even
and odd functions' that we

could technically leave out
here, but which I think is a good place to bring in. And the fact that there are
many, many places in our

advanced treatment that will

these things mean, that

perhaps this is a nice place
to bring it into play. So I call this an aside
and it's about

even and odd functions. When we have the case that 'f of
x' equals 'f of 'minus x'',

that's the case where in terms
of the graph you have symmetry with respect to the y-axis such

'even function'. And I'll come back in a moment

The counterpart to an even
function as you may guess almost from the association
of ideas is

called an 'odd function'. Now an odd function is one for
which 'f of x' is the negative

of 'f of 'minus x''. See for 'f' to be odd, 'f of x'
has to be the negative of

'f of 'minus x''. Now what does this

This height would be called 'f
of x1' and this height here would be called 'f
of 'minus x1''.

And to say that these two
heights are equal in magnitude

but opposite in sign
means what? That these two lengths are equal
but on opposite sides of

the x-axis. In other words, here's
'f of x1'. 'f of 'minus x1'' is the height

the axis, the other one must

if 'f' is odd, what it

the origin with any point on

the curve, if you extend that
line that line will meet the

curve again, such that these
distances here will be equal. This is called symmetry with

By the way, an example of

'Minus x cubed'. And 'minus 'minus x cubed''

this portion

would equal this portion. And by the way, maybe you can

Notice that when I dealt with
'y' equals 'x squared' I had an even function. The exponent was even.

When I dealt with 'y'
equals 'x cubed', I had an odd function. The exponent was odd.

And by the way, there
are other examples. But for the time being, notice

x', I have 'minus x

cubed' plus 'minus x'. That of course, is just 'minus

And that's minus the quantity
'x cubed + x'. That when I replace 'x' by

the sign here. In other words, that would be an
example for which 'f of x' is minus 'f of 'minus x''.

By the way, while we're dealing

number is either even or odd
but not both, it's rather important to notice that a
function need not be either

even or odd. And by the way, if you think of

Obviously you understand that

Or if we wanted to go into more

Just to give you an idea of what

This will come back to be more

a connecting thread here

as long as we're talking about
even and odd functions, all I want to see is the following
identity.

If you write ''f of x' plus
'f of 'minus x'' over 2.

tenth derivatives all have a meaning that gives you
more information

than what came before. Don't be deceived by the fact
that in other applications that you never go past the
second derivative means that

there is no value to knowing how
higher order derivatives are related to plotting
curves.

At any rate, I think this is
enough of an introduction to the topic of curve plotting
and curve sketching.

We'll pursue these topics
further in our next lectures. So until next time, goodbye.
